Award.AwardTitle: Concurrent Design for Functional Reliability and Failure Prognosis of Complex Engineered Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to create a new system design paradigm, referred to as resilience-driven system design, which enables concurrent developments of reliable system functions and accurate prognosis of function failures of complex engineered systems under uncertainty. Resilience implies the ability to sense and withstand adverse events, and to recover from the effects of the adverse events. This research will quantify engineering resilience with a rigorous mathematical formula, develop new methods for predictive resilience analysis, and further create a new design paradigm that offers a unique framework to consider prognosis of system failures and failure mitigation/recovery activities in the early system design stage. The research findings will be validated and demonstrated using benchmarking design problems, as well as practical design applications addressing the critical demands in aviation systems and sustainable energy systems based on the research collaborations with two leading industry partners.

If successful, this research will lead to a design paradigm shift from conventional design for reliability to design for resilience by developing new design theory and tools. The research results will promote the understanding on preventing system failures through designing resilience into engineered systems. The new system design paradigm will likely stimulate growth in several high technology industries such as the multi-billion dollar green energy generation, general aviation, automobile, and more which suffer from catastrophic system failures and high maintenance costs at the post system design stages. This research will also offers unique research and educational experiences for researchers across the fields of engineering design, health monitoring and failure prognosis, and will train students in an interdisciplinary learning environment. A wide range of dissemination and outreach programs will be accomplished, with emphasis on promoting data sharing, attracting students to engineering career and research opportunities, and participation from women and underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research project, the researchers addressed a fundamental design challenge of creating failure resilient engineered systems and investigated a new system design framework that concurrently integrates system function design with functional failure prognostics. Through this research project, fundamental new knowledge has been created on how prognosis can be designed into an engineered system to enhance its failure resilience, which furnishes a better understanding of how engineered system can achieve resilience and further how resilient engineered system can be designed. A set of new system modeling, analysis and design methodology and techniques have been created within three research thrusts: engineering resilience quantification, predictive resilience analysis and resilience driven system design, leading to 15 published journal articles in prestigious peer reviewed journals by the research team, and two best paper awards from IEEE Reliability Society in 2012 and ASME Design Automation Conference in 2013, respectively. Through collaborations with national laboratory and industrial partners, the developed methodology and techniques have been applied to a variety of practical engineering system design applications, such as aircraft systems, wind turbines, microelectronics systems, battery energy storage systems as well power transformers.  

The research project has offered unique research and educational experiences for researchers across the fields of engineering system design, health monitoring and failure prognosis. The research team has broadly disseminated the research findings to different professional societies and research communities, through annual ASME international design engineering technical conference (IDETC), IEEE annual conference on prognostics and health management (PHM), AIAA annual Science and Technology conference (SciTech), as well as the IISE annual industrial and system engineering research conferences (ISERC). Students involved in this research project have been trained in an interdisciplinary learning environment, leading two Ph.D. graduates with one takes an academic position as an assistant professor in a research university and another becomes an engineer in industry, all in the United States. In addition, two undergraduate students, one Native American and one female minority, have been attracted to participate in this project through the Engineering 2020 program in the principle investigator’s home institute. After their involvement in this research project, they have both decided to continue their studies in graduate school for advanced engineering degrees and pursue a career in engineering. Moreover, through participation of K-12 outreach programs including the Engineering Summer Camp and Kansas Project Lead the Way (PLTW), the research findings of this project has been broadly disseminated and utilized to educate younger generations and encourage them to further pursue a career in engineering.
